message.content:
gici | K : square root of P. Aurelia equals left five twenty minus three hundred right divided by five twenty equals forty-two point three. square root of P . datum equals left three sixty minus two hundred right divided by three sixty equals forty-four point four percent. seventeen
owaw | Laboratory Experiment Two
z6xu | Thomas Park's, nineteen forty-eight, Three Grain Beetle species (Tribolium confusum, Tribolium castaneum and Oryzaephilus surinamensis)
knw2 | Variable - Climatic conditions (temperature and moisture) and food availability
mxnw | Monitoring of competitive outcome (highest fitness) among three grain beetles
bdx4 | Moisture gradient: Dry - Moist
l01c | Temperature gradient: Hot - Warm - Cold
yphh | Demonstrations of Fundamental and Realised niches
3yor | Tribolium castaneum: hot-moist specialist
f9sc | Tribolium confusum: cold-dry specialist
o5l0 | Fundamental niches
c1wq | Hot-moist versus cold-dry specialists
gr2b | Both species of beetles exhibit identical climate niches in allopatry
jkky | Climatic extremes represented in only one of the two species, with the other species occupying the middle range
7vxr | In sympatric medium, Tribolium confusum always eliminates Oryzaephilus surinamensis because of its higher rate of reproduction and better predation ability
qzyn | An extra dimension, for example space in the form of glass tubes, allows co-existence of the two species
rcl1 | Oryzaephilus
9qpf | Interspecific Competition - Field Experiments
y5cx | Joseph H. Connell's, nineteen sixty-one, Tidal Barnacles (Balanus balanoides and Chthamalus stellatus)
hexk | Adult Chthamalus usually occur above Balanus
c05v | Chthamalus larvae do settle in Balanus Lower Tide Zone
1ytq | Adult Balanus never in high tide zones (due to desiccation)
tkax | Methodology - Connell suspected that adult Balanus out competed adult Chthamalus. He kept removing Balanus adult in lower zones in experimental plots in one set as well as removing Chthamalus from upper zone in another
6mpz | Results
bi1x | One. Removing Balanus from lower zones caused Chthamalus to survive
bnve | Two. Balanus never settled in upper zone even as Chthamalus was removed there
7gvc | Conclusion
jf19 | One. Adult barnacles compete over space in lower zones
6hx6 | Two. Balanus is superior (crushing Chthamalus) leaving a small realized niche (upper zone) for Chthamalus
xcql | Three. Fundamental niche of Chthamalus includes dry upper zones where Balanus cannot withstand desiccation twenty-three
xcxb | Interspecific competition - Field Experiment Two
ci51 | Brown and Davidson's Granivorous Desert Ants and Rodents in Arizona
jaj7 | Ants and rodents were observed to overlap in seed utilization, and the question was then: Are they competing for a limited resource equals seeds?
uc0w | Experimental Design
494y | One. Ant-Removal Plots were sprayed with pesticides regularly
5whs | Two. Rodent-Removal Plots were fenced and subjected to intensive trapping protocols
kigc | Three. Both ants and rodents removed
k5st | Four. Control Plots with both ants and rodents present
d8e8 | Results
gb7b | One. Rodents removed - Ant colonies increase above control plots
jxu0 | Two. Ants removed - Rodents densities increase above control plots
l1bb | Conclusions
i3e0 | One. As one competitor is removed the remaining increase. Density Compensation occurs - Release of extra resources that is no more utilized by the removed species
78dj | Two. Ants and rodents have overlapping limited food resource niche, seeds, over which they compete
c1pj | Interspecific Competition - Field Experiment Three
6v9y | Paine's, nineteen sixty-six, starfish (Pisaster) in rocky intertidal zones of the U.S.: Predator-mediated Coexistence
deen | Pisaster, a keystone predator, predates differentially on the dominant competitors (bivalves and acorn barnacles)
27bo | Removal of the predator showed that the more dominant competitors crowded out the inferior species (goose barnacles, limpets and chitons)
72k6 | This reduced the total number of coexisting species from fifteen to eight
emhp | A classic example of Top-Down control of communities, trophic cascading effects or predator-mediated coexistence at lower trophic levels. A B Starfish (Pisaster)
tcgw | Ecological Release (Habitat) - Natural Experiments One
4d8s | Jared M. Diamond's, nineteen seventy-five, Ground Doves on Papua New Guinea and associated islands (Chalcophaps indica, Chalcophaps stephani and Gallicolumba rufigula)
1cmq | Mainland, New Guinea: All three Ground doves living sympatrically in distinct habitats, no overlap
u8s6 | Large island, Bagabag: Only two species - In the absence of Gallicolumba rufigula, Chalcophaps stephani expands its niche to include inland rainforest
86m5 | Very small islands, New Britain, Tolokiwa, Karkar, Espiritu Santo - Only one species, Chalcophaps indica, present and it is able to occupy all three types
lzzv | Conclusion
623p | Fundamental niches of the three doves shown only when in allopatry
50lp | When in sympatry, each species excludes the other two from its specialized habitat equals Contiguous Allopatry
i4nn | There is competitive exclusion on New Guinea and competitive release elsewhere
nuk3 | Ecological Release (Habitat) - Natural Experiments Two
y2cn | Jared M. Diamond's, nineteen seventy-five - Two Honeyeaters on three Papua New Guinea mountains
hgm4 | Fundamental niche: similar - Phylidonyris guiseyi equals three hundred to three thousand five hundred meters; Phylidonyris peristriata equals two hundred to three thousand eight hundred fifty meters
nc42 | Fundamental niche: overlap
tbfm | eighty-eight percent. Ranged reduced, allopatry to sympatry, from two hundred to three thousand seven hundred to three thousand to three thousand eight hundred fifty meters:
ok18 | twenty-five percent. Realised niche of inferior species, Phylidonyris peristriata, only twenty-five percent of the fundamental niche
pgqe | Another example of habitat related altitudinal, vertical spatial, Ecological Release
qo9m | Contiguous Allopatry - Natural Experiment Three H. C. Heller's, nineteen seventy-one, chipmunks in Sierra Nevada mountains, California
e7zz | Ecological Release/Niche Shift - Natural Experiment Four
lhzk | Nils-Arvid Nilsson's, nineteen sixty-three, Salmonids in Swedish Lakes, Asymmetric Niche Shift
wdpw | Assessment of diets, six food types, of two Salmonids
twiq | Great overlap in food utilization in allopatry
cchx | Large crustaceans, C, Insect larvae, D, and terrestrial insects, E, preferred by both species in allopatry
2vma | In sympatry;
z4aw | Char specializes greatly, sixty percent, on small crustaceans, B, greatly reducing consumption of insect larvae, D, and terrestrial insects, E
mo0p | Trout largely remains a generalist in sympatry. Large crustaceans and molluscs are shared in sympatry
tyxr | Char's dietary composition greatly changed in sympatry; Trout's not
txaa | Limiting Similarity - Character Displacement One
qz8s | Tom Fenchel's, nineteen seventy-five, Character Displacement in Marine Mud Snails, Denmark
y7de | Measurement of lengths of two species of snails; Hydrobia ulvae and Hydrobia ventrosa
rukn | Shell length correlated with food size
